definitions.definition: an amount that is extra or more than you need

examples.text: Wheat was in surplus that year.
After meeting domestic needs any surplus will be exported.
Agricultural surpluses lead to the disposal of thousands of tonnes of food every year.
This surplus of food led to an unusual increase in the bird population.

definitions.definition: the amount by which the amount of money received is greater than the amount of money spent

examples.text: The balance of payments was in surplus last year (= the value of exports was greater than the value of imports).
Japan runs a large current-account surplus.
The pension fund is in surplus.
a projected surplus of $5.6 trillion over ten years

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French sourplus, from medieval Latin superplus, from super- ‘in addition’ + plus ‘more’.
